tossups.question: The Omphalion is a round stone that these leaders stood on while being crowned. One of these leaders won the Battle of Kleidion and allegedly blinded the defeated army, earning the nickname “Bulgar-Slayer.” Another of these leaders, married to the notorious Theodora, created a namesake law code that served as the basis for Western civil law. For the point, name these rulers who included Justinian and ruled from Constantinople.
tossups.answer: Byzantine Emperors [prompt on Roman Emperors; accept Eastern Roman Emperors] [Blake Neff]

tossups.question: This island was policed by British soldiers nicknamed the “Black and Tans.” A program  based on the “three F’s” was adopted by its Land League, led by Charles Stewart Parnell. William Cosgrave was the first president of a “Free State” based here. Isaac Butt led its “Home  Rule” movement, and Sinn Féin is the political wing of its namesake “Republican Army.” For the point, name this site of an 1840s potato famine.

As a colony, this state’s legislature authorized representatives to vote for independence with  the Halifax Resolves. After William Tryon raised taxes and built a large governor’s mansion in this colony, Herman Husband led a protest movement that was defeated in the Battle of Alamance. The existence of Tuscarora Indians with blue eyes could explain the fate of some people from this colony. For 10 points, name this colony, the site of the Regulator Movement and the Roanoke Settlement.

In 1980, this city’s mob boss Angelo Bruno was assassinated. It is the home of a black liberation group called MOVE which was bombed by officials in 1985. After serving as mayor of this city for much of the 1990s, Ed Rendell became governor of its state. This city is currently led by Michael Nutter and is served by the SEPTA public transportation network. This city was the hub of the national bicentennial celebrations that occurred in 1976. For the point, name this largest city in Pennsylvania.
